Another approach is to expand the definition of a node to include 
more tha=
n one unique input and output, and re-introduce a trained 
genome as a node=
. And let evolutionary computation discover the 
applicability of the embed=
ded knowledge to the current task at hand.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "K=
enneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Christofer, it's an interesting i=
dea but I think it may be 
difficult 
> to implement in practice because of=
 the nonlinear relationship 
among 
> different components of the solution.=
  That is, just because some 
> things change or are updated more than othe=
rs during learning does 
> not imply that they should continue to do so or =
even that it was a 
> good idea in the first place (because the problem mig=
ht be 
> deceptive).  It's a pretty complicated topic but I think the 
> fu=
ndamental issue is that evolutionary computation is effective in 
> part be=
cause it avoids trying to excplicitly assign credit to the 
> separate part=
s of a solution.  So when we move to trying to extract 
> explicit informat=
ion about what belongs with what, we are somewhat 
> undoing this implicit =
appeal.
> 
> Nevertheless, the idea that solutions need some kind of modula=
rity 
> or at least a pattern behind them makes sense.  It's just the 
> ap=
proach that is the tricky issue.  Have you taken a look at 
> HyperNEAT?  I=
t is able to evolve networks with large-scale patterns 
> that can be modul=
ar to varying degrees.
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "christof=
er_fransson" 
> <christofer_fransson@> wrote:

e human brain has different areas that solve different kind of

twork to divide a problem into smaller sub 
problems

ordinates (x,y,z)

orming well 
in

> > epoch

idn't have to be changed 
much

ate" towards each other
> > - Nodes close to each other have a higher proba=
bility to form a

at in someway tries to be 
modular.

 possible to do individual

k.
